hero.middle: Founder of the Republic of Turkiye
hero.bottom: He is a great soldier, politician and statesman who fit 11 wars, 24 medals, 7 decorations, 13 books, 1 country and millions of free people into his 57-year life. With love, respect, gratitude and longing...

words.text: My humble body will one day become soil, but the Republic of Turkiye will live on forever.

life.title: Atatürk's life
life.bottom_text: Seeing me does not necessarily mean seeing my face. If you understand my ideas and my feelings thats enough.

life_text.t_1: Mustafa Kemal, born in 1881 in Thessaloniki, was the fourth child of Mrs. Zübeyde Hanım and Ali Rıza Efendi. Initially starting his education at Hafız Mehmed Efendi Neighborhood School, he later transferred to Şemsi Efendi School due to dissatisfaction with the former.
life_text.t_2: In 1893, following his father's passing, Mustafa Kemal took a break from his education and spent approximately 5 months with his mother at his uncle's farm in Langaza.
life_text.t_3: Returning to Thessaloniki after his rural hiatus, Mustafa Kemal continued his education, first at Selanik Mülkiye Rüşdiyesi and then at Selanik Military Rüşdiyesi, where he adopted the name 'Kemal' given by his math teacher.
life_text.t_4: Completing his middle school education, he proceeded to Manastır Military High School, where his interest in history, literature, and French flourished.
life_text.t_5: Subsequently, Mustafa Kemal pursued higher education in Istanbul, graduating from the Istanbul Military Academy in 1902 and the War Academy in 1905.
life_text.t_6: Commencing his career, he completed his internship at the 5th Army in Damascus before assuming roles at the 3rd Army headquarters and later the 3rd Army Thessaloniki 2nd Reserve Division.
life_text.t_7: In 1911, he volunteered for the Tripolitanian War and later participated in the Balkan Wars, where he played a pivotal role in the recapture of Edirne.
life_text.t_8: Joining the 19th Division Command during World War I, he distinguished himself in the Gallipoli Campaign, halting the Allied advance.
life_text.t_9: Post-war, Mustafa Kemal spearheaded the Turkish War of Independence, convening crucial congresses and serving as the President of the Grand National Assembly of Turkiye in 1923.
life_text.t_10: During his presidency, he implemented significant reforms across various sectors, leading Turkiye towards modernization and global recognition.
life_text.t_11: In 1934, he was granted the surname 'Atatürk' by the Grand National Assembly of Turkiye.
life_text.t_12: In his personal life, he married Latife Hanım in 1923, and the couple had a brief marriage until 1925. Additionally, he adopted a boy named Mustafa.
life_text.t_13: Facing declining health from 1937, Atatürk spent his final days under medical care in Istanbul, passing away on November 10, 1938, at Dolmabahçe Palace.

family.title: Atatürk's Family
family.bottom_text: His mother is Mrs Zübeyde and his father is Ali Rıza

family_text_mother.t_1: Mrs. Zübeyde, Atatürk's mother, was the daughter of Feyzullah Aga from the Hacı Sofu family. She was an intelligent, prudent woman, devoted to religion and traditions. She wanted her son to start the neighborhood school with traditional hymns. However, as we will see below, she did not prevent her son from growing up in the manner required by the times, and especially after her husband's death, she tried as much as she could to provide him with a good education.
family_text_mother.t_2: An example of her prudence and high sense of honor can be seen in the following incident. While they were still in Thessaloniki, when she found out what was going on in a meeting her son had with some of his friends who were working against the rule of Abdul Hamid II, she was afraid of the consequences of working against the sultan, but when Mustafa Kemal told her about it, she understood the problem and said, 'If you have secret things, let me hide them, it is difficult to succeed, it is more natural to perish' and then she said the following:
family_text_mother.t_3: ... my son, if one day, after these things happen, I do not see you with those who have honor and dignity, then I will be sad. I have not studied as much as you, I do not know as much as you do, I would not try to prevent you from doing what you see and understand, but be careful, the main thing is to succeed, try to succeed.

family_text_father.t_1: He was a native of Thessaloniki. Their distant ancestors left Vidin and settled in Serres, and from there they came to Thessaloniki. Ali Rıza Efendi first worked as a foundation clerk in Thessaloniki. Although Ataturk said that he remembered him little, he remembered his intelligence and determination and said that he was a modern-minded person. After the war with Serbia started in 1876, an 'Asakiri Milliye' battalion was established from volunteers in Thessaloniki and Ali Efendi became a first lieutenant there.
family_text_father.t_2: II. After this and similar units were disbanded upon Abdulhamid's delusion, it seems that Ali Efendi retired from the foundations and became a revenue officer. He later started a private life and worked as a timber merchant.

battles.title: Wars in which Ataturk participated
battles.bottom_text: War must be necessary and vital. Unless the life of the nation is in danger, war is murder.

battles_1.t_1: The War of Independence Front, which was a front where the Turkish army fought with great determination, lasted until March 31, 1921 and was very bloody. After this war, Mustafa Kemal explained the importance of this war with the following statement: 'It was a war that defeated the bad luck of the nation'

battles_2.t_1: One of the strongest fronts that the Ottoman Empire fought during the First World War was the Çanakkale Front. On the Gallipoli Front, one of the bloodiest fronts of the First World War, the war was fought against England and France who wanted to help Russia. The underlying reason why France and England wanted to help Russia was to strengthen Russia's weakening economy and enable Russia to exclude the Ottoman Empire from the war. With these details, France and England launched an attack on the Dardanelles Front.
battles_2.t_2: The Battle of Çanakkale, which first started with naval battles, progressed with the British and French suffering heavy losses during the passage through the Dardanelles. Although these states, which suffered heavy losses at sea, planned to attack the Ottoman Empire by land by landing troops in Gallipoli, the Turkish army under the command of Mustafa Kemal Atatürk in Gallipoli managed to successfully prevent this attack, as it did at sea. Mustafa Kemal Atatürk's success against enemy soldiers in the Gallipoli Peninsula enabled him to be promoted to the rank of colonel.
battles_2.t_3: Approximately 253,000 officers, privates and non-commissioned officers were martyred during these wars. The enemy armies, the French and Italians, suffered as many losses as the Turks and withdrew from Anafartalar and Arıburnu on December 20, 1915.

battles_3.t_1: On March 11, 1916, Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, as the Corps Commander, fought against the Russians and the Armenians who united with the Russians on the Diyarbakır, Muş and Bitlis fronts. Victory was achieved against the enemy on the Bitlis front on 8 August 1916 and on the Muş front on 14 May 1917, and these regions were liberated from enemy occupation. On April 1, 1916, Mustafa Kemal Atatürk was given the rank of Brigadier General for his success in the Diyarbakır, Muş and Bitlis fronts, also known as the Eastern (Caucasian) Front. After the success on this front, Russian troops were withdrawn.

battles_4.t_1: The British, who had the Suez Canal in 1914, attacked Gaza in 1917. The wars that started here are called the First and Second Gaza Wars. After the Turkish success, the British advanced on Gaza. Following this development, the British reinforced their military forces with reinforcements and exerted strong pressure on the Palestinian Front.
battles_4.t_2: Mustafa Kemal Atatürk İldırım, who will head the future 7th Army Command, has resigned from this position due to a disagreement with the army commander, General Falkenhayn. On October 24, 1917, the British attacked with 138,000 soldiers and won the Battle of Birusseba-Gaza. In 1918, Mustafa Kemal Atatürk returned to the 7th Army Command from which he had resigned and commanded the army against the British. The British, who increased the number of their soldiers to 460 thousand, were able to cross Palestine.
battles_4.t_3: On this front, Mustafa Kemal Atatürk fought against both British and armed armed groups. Finally, he was able to stop the British, and after the peace treaty of Mondros on October 31, 1918, he was appointed commander of Army Group Lightning.

battles_5.t_1: Mustafa Kemal Atatürk personally came to the front fighting against the Greeks on July 18, 1921 and it was discovered. A chance is obtained against the Greek army of Atatürk, who ordered a withdrawal to Sakarya to re-strengthen the army. On August 12, 1921, Atatürk, who received the rank of commander-in-chief fighting on this front, became the head of the army with this title.

battles_6.t_1: The war, also known as the Turkish-Italian War of 1911-1921, took place between the Ottoman Empire and Italy. This war generally took place in the Adriatic Sea, the Aegean Islands, the Dardanelles and the Red Sea. The Ottoman Empire, which failed as a result of dividing its military power among many wars after the First Balkan War started at the same time, was defeated against Italy and lost the Tripolitania, Fezzan and Cyrenaica regions as a result of this defeat. Later, the Libyan State was established with the unification of these regions.
battles_6.t_2: Although the Italian Forces besieged Rhodes and the Dodecanese during the war, the Dodecanese was given back to the Ottomans with the Ushi Treaty signed after the war. During the Tripoli War, Mustafa Kemal Atatürk showed his success in the military field by leading the Battle of Tobruk with the rank of major.
battles_6.t_3: Due to the Balkan Wars that started on October 8, the Ottoman Empire agreed to an agreement with Italy and withdrew from the war. As a result of the war, Italy's conditions were accepted and the treaty was signed in Ouchy, Switzerland, on October 15, 1912.

battles_7.t_1: The Ottoman Empire, which fought against four countries at once, lost the Balkan Wars. After this war, the Treaty of London was signed. According to this treaty, the Ottoman Empire lost its Balkan and Thracian lands. It arose as a result of the Balkan States' inability to share the lands they had won among themselves in the Second Balkan War. Meanwhile, Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, who was serving in the army command in Tripoli, returned to Istanbul after the end of this war and was reassigned to Gallipoli with the outbreak of the Second Balkan War.
battles_7.t_2: Due to his success in Thrace during the Second Balkan War, Mustafa Kemal Atatürk was appointed as the attaché in Sofia. Mustafa Kemal's military success was again effective in the Ottoman Empire regaining some of the lands it lost in Gallipoli and Thrace in the First Balkan War in the Second Balkan War.

battles_8.t_1: Mahmut Şevket, who was the Minister of War at that time, was assigned to suppress this rebellion. Mustafa Kemal Atatürk himself was among the force assigned to stop the rebellion under the command of Mahmut Şevket. The army, including Mahmut Şevket and Atatürk, suppressed the rebellion within a month.

battles_9.t_1: It is a large-scale protest against the government established in Istanbul after the announcement of the Second Constitution. It lasted 13 days in total. The struggle, which started with a military structure, later acquired a religious dimension with the intervention of religious sections. Rebel soldiers surrounded Istanbul for 7 days with the rebellion that ensured the resignation of the government in Istanbul. It is still unknown for what purpose these soldiers rebelled and whether this rebellion was planned or conscious.
battles_9.t_2: Atatürk, who was directly involved in the March 31 disaster and observed the events, fought against the rebelling soldiers with General İzzettin Çalışlar. The success of the Action Army formed by Atatürk and the events of the March 31 Incident were later published in the National Newspaper in Atatürk's language.
